Build a mobile-first native iOS and Android app using React Native and Expo called “Say It Anyway: Grief Journal.” This is a private, offline-first journaling app that lets users leave messages for loved ones who have passed away. All data must be stored locally on the device; no cloud backend is required.

The main screen should display a grid of recipient cards in a mobile-native contact style. Each recipient includes a name, nickname, optional gender (Male, Female, Non-Binary, Decline to State), photo, date of birth, date of death, notes, and the timestamp of the most recent message. Allow one recipient to be marked as the default. The header should include a button to add a new recipient and a “!!!” button that opens a Support Resources screen.

Each recipient can have multiple messages. A message can be either text or audio and includes a timestamp, text content, optional compressed voicemail-quality audio, a speech-to-text transcript, and a hidden flag (default false). The message list should show only non-hidden messages by default and allow users to hide a message without deleting it. Place the add-message button at the top of the screen (not near Android system navigation).

Users should be able to create text notes or record audio messages. For audio messages, record and store the audio locally, compress it, then convert speech to text using an on-device or non-paid speech-to-text solution compatible with Expo or React Native (do not require Google Cloud or other paid APIs). After saving any message, return the user to the main contacts screen.

After a message is saved, run a mental-health screening process using context-aware, rule-based pattern analysis rather than simple keyword matching. The logic should detect first-person expressions of distress, hopelessness, or self-harm intent while avoiding false positives when harm is described as happening to someone else. Structure this so it can be upgraded to more advanced NLP later.

If a message is flagged, automatically show a Support Resources screen with calm, empathetic language and links or call actions for the 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline, Crisis Text Line, and other free emergency mental-health resources. The same screen should open when the user taps the “!!!” button on the main screen.

Include a settings screen that allows users to choose from 6–8 calming, visually pleasing color themes. Store the selected theme locally and apply it app-wide. Use Expo-compatible local storage (such as SQLite or SecureStore) for recipients, messages, audio files, hidden flags, theme selection, and default recipient. Design all screens to be mobile-first, one-hand friendly, accessible, and calm, avoiding clinical or alarmist language.
